Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 07:58PM X3sMom wrote: Maybe your onc was afraid pronouncing you NED might give you "false hope" that you were cancer free. Stage 4 does mean it's always possible for it to start to grow again enough to be detected by tm's or scans. But knowing you are NED is an exciting place to be for however long it last, hopefully till there's a cure!    Praise the Lord for your low tumor marker and clean scan. May it last for a long time.

Posts.Title: Just wanted to check in... LuAnnH CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 01:41AM X3sMom wrote: This could have been "my granddaughter".  "Grandma Test"I was out walking with my 4-year-old granddaughter. She picked up something off the ground and started to put it in her mouth. I took the item away from her and I asked her not to do that."Why?" my granddaughter asked."Because it's been on the ground. You don't know where it's been, it's dirty, and probably has germs," I replied. At this point, my granddaughter looked at me with total admiration and asked, "Grandma, how do you know all this stuff? You are so smart."    I was thinking quickly, "All Grandmas know this stuff. It's on the Grandma Test. You have to know it, or they don't let you be a Grandma." We walked along in silence for 2 or 3 minutes, but she was evidently pondering this new information. "Oh...I get it!" she beamed, "So if you don't pass the test, you have to be the Grandpa." "Exactly," I replied.
Posts.Title: Bring a smile, or share a laugh Fitztwins china

Posts.Content: X3sMom wrote:  Ladies, I haven't looked at these in awhile so maybe you could check and see if I left out anything or if there is a better post to find this info. I'm posting it for Bigelow1, post dated today Nov. 13.   God Bless, Glenda Breastcancer Abbreviations Dictionary Addy ~ email address AI ~ Aromatase inhibitor (Femara, Arimidex, etc.)  ALND ~ Axillary lymph node dissection AND ~ axillary node dissection ARM ~ Axillary Reverse Mapping, a new surgical procedure that marks the lymph nodes draining the arm before surgery so the surgeon can preserve them, in an effort to lower lymphedema risk B9 ~ Not Cancer BC ~ Breast Cancer Bi-Lat ~ bilateral, Mastectomy of both breast BM ~ Bilateral Mastectomy BRCA ~ BReast CAncer gene BS ~ Breast specialist/Surgeon Bump ~ written to edit a thread up in the listings so someone can find it. Bx ~ Biopsy CT scan ~ Computerized Tomography, used to image the structures of the body, especially head, neck and trunk. DCIS ~ Ductal Carcinoma In Situ DD ~  Dose dense , Dear Daughter DH ~ Dear Husband DP ~ Dear partner DS ~ Dear Son Dx ~ Diagnosis DW~ Dear Wife ER ~ Estrogen Receptive FIL ~ Father in law FNA ~ Fine Needle Aspiration HER2 + or - ~  whether your tumor overexpresses the HER2 protein or not HT ~ Anti-hormone Therapy HRT ~ Hormone Replacement Therapy Hx ~ History IBC ~ Inflamatory Breast Cancer IDC ~ Invasive Ductal Carcinoma ILC ~ Invasive Lobular Carcinoma IMHO ~ In My Humble Opinion LCIS ~ Lobular Carcinoma In Situ LE ~ Lymphedema Lump ~Lumpectomy Lt ~ Left Mast ~Mastectomy Mets ~ Metastasis Metster~ a person with Metastasis cancer MIA ~ Missing In Action Mil ~ Mother in law MLD ~ manual lymphatic drainage Mojo ~ Sex , or lack of sex MRI ~ Magnetic Resonance Imaging MRSA ~ Methcillin-resistant Staphylococcus Aureus, a bacterium that causes an infection that is hard to treat MUGA ~ tests to see if your heart is strong enough to withstand chemo NED ~No evidence of Disease NP ~ Nurse Practitioners  ODAAT ~ One day at a time OMG ~ Oh my gosh Omph (or Ooph) ~ Ovary removal (oopherectomy) ONC ~ Oncologist OT ~ off topic (a post that isn't about BC) Path ~ pathology PBM - prophylactic bilateral mastectomy PE ~ pleural effusion PET scan ~ Positron Emission Tomography, used to image metabolically active cells, such as cancer cells. PET-CT scan ~ a combination of PET and CT which superimposes the metabolically active cells that 'liglht up' on the bodily structures so that the radiologist is reading a single image. PICC ~ peripherally inserted central catheter. When used (occasionally) for chemo, it is sometimes known as an 'arm port'. More often used for IV antibiotics such as may be required for MRSA and other serious bacterial infections. PM ~ personal message Ppl  ~ people PR ~ Progesterone Receptive PS ~ Plastic Surgeon QOL ~ quality of life RA ~ Rad onc ~ radiation oncologist Rt ~ Right Rx ~ prescription SE ~ Side Effects SNB - sentinel node biopsy SND ~ Sentinel Node Dissection Stats ~ statistics TN (Triple Negative) in regards to negative status for ER/PR and Her2neu status TMI-Too much information TX - treatment TY ~ thank you US ~ Ultrasound WBC ~ White Blood Cells WBR ~ Whole-Brain Radiotherapy CID = Contra-Indication CDT = Complete Decongestive Therapy   Tx = treatment US = Ultrasound Kendra's Mom Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2009 02:00PM X3sMom wrote: She started with Abraxane/Avastin for mets to the liver and after only 6 treatments, she had only two tumors left (they were innumberable). Those were gone after RFA. Then, she was NED till it came in her bones which she did Fasledex and something else that started with an A.  He took her off that last month and started her back on the Abraxane/Avastin again because it "hadn't quit working". It worked so well for her, she didn't need it anymore.  I don't know if this is normal or not. Her second treatment will be on the 30th with tm's again. So, I guess we'll know something after that.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 03:16PM X3sMom wrote: Heather, I went to the onc today with Kendra. She's been having stomach pains. He has her on Faslodex and Zometa right now. The Faslodex is because she's est+ too.  They took out her ovaries this Spring. Faslodex works as well as or better than Arimidex (chemical name: anastrozole), an aromatase inhibitor, in slowing or stopping the growth of metastatic (breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body), hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women after tamoxifen has stopped working. Today he said he might not give her the Faslodex next month because it may be causing the pain in her stomach.  He told her the body makes est. in the adrenal glands is why she's on it.

Posts.Title: Feel like that flaky friend texasrose361 X3sMom

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2010 12:56PM - edited Apr 22, 2010 01:04PM by X3sMom Renee, Kendra's had a rough time lately. She was in the hospital 5 days...after she threw up lots of blood (in her stool too). They gave her a Protonix IV and 2 units of blood. Then sent her home because her Platlets wouldn't go above 29 and her wbc was only 2.7, so they couldn't do the GI scope. Then last week she had that done and showed nothing bad, Praise the Lord. They said the low bc and meds caused the bleeding. Then last week they also took one and a half liters of fluid off her adomen which also came back normal..no infection or cancer. PTL.  Today's her first Ixempra (one every 3 weeks) with Avastin. Her hair has grown back some and she's not looking forward to losing it again. She's on the Fentanol patch so we're hoping that will help control any se. DH is somewhat better since he has realized the seriousness of stage IV. Her DD has a job at Sonic and is at home as little as possible and lives in DeNile. DS, 11 yrs, is still momma's boy but "boy" being the key word. God help us all if the doesn't take his medicine. Me, I'm still Kendra's steady rock....but if truth be told, she's my rock. I've never know in my 61 yrs anyone as strong, couragous and determined as her. Pattih, thanks for the info. Kendra is really tired alot and in pain from the spine mets (whick she had 12 rads for) and low blood counts already. She' come in every 10 days for blood work. Chanisawz, thanks for bumping the thread. Scary reading...but if anybody can get through it, Kendra can. She's gotten into her art and has just finihed an acrylic painting to submit to  the "Oncology on Canvas" book. She's also filling out the paperwork for SSD and to receiving half of her insurance benefits. She hoping to not have to go back to work. BC Sisters, thanks for your prayers and concern. My daughter is one special lady! (Edited to correct spelling..Kendra gets her perfectionism for me.)

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 04:04AM X3sMom wrote: Monique, Kendra had mets to the liver last Nov. 08 and her onc put her on Abraxane/Avastin. After 6 treatments all but 2 of the innumberable lesions we cleared up. Those were gone with RFA. She was NED for a couple months before it came back in her bones. She went on Fasledex and something else then. All that background to say last Friday's PET showed progression in her liver again so Monday he started her back on Abraxane/Avastin again because it worked so well for her. You gals here are a great source of imformation. It's wonderful going into the onc office already knowing what something he say 'means'. Knowing what he's talking about helps so we can ask the right questions. I've not heard of liver tumors pulsating causing scar tissue. What does that mean? I've not heard of 'pulsating' before. God bless you sweetheart. I'm praying you and your onc find the right treatment plan. Don't be afraid to ask him to explain something to you.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2010 11:18AM X3sMom wrote: I just read Kendra's post again. Her onc and I decided to have the BRCA tests done, her last week in the hospital. We thought we needed to know for her daughter's sake. I wish she could have been here to tell Kalah that she did not have the mutation. She would have been so happy. Kalah will still have to get mammos at 25 yrs. old but if her mom had been positive her chances of getting breast cancer would be 6 times greater. I come here every now and then hoping to see the ages go up but still there are too many young women with small children getting this horrible disease. Praying for a cure!
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2009 06:20PM X3sMom wrote: Sweetheart, I'm 60 and cancer-less. However, I've been on this journey with my daughter for seven years (She's 37 now). Mets since Nov 08, liver first, now bones and liver again. I go to all of her appointments with her too because she's quiet and doesn't ask questions. We completely trust her onc but I do have questions that he doesn't mind at all to answer...even taking the time to show us her scans. This group of ladies are amazing and very helpful. The more you read here and your own research will help you to not be afraid of the unknown. I have found,  knowing just what we are dealing with gives us a lot of peace. So, you are welcomed here to ask questions and learn as much as you can so you can be a stronger advocate for your Mom. It's great having questions ready for her onc while you're there instead of thinkingof them after you leave. It's also great to have knowledge of what he's talking because you read it here. My "THANKS" again to the couragous women who are willing to share their experiences so they can help each other and us!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2009 04:38AM X3sMom wrote: I discovered that going to our 'home page' and typing a word or phrase in the box brings up several interesting articles with good info like this. (I typed in "ginseng") I found this plants list that contains estrogens: dong quai, ginseng, evening primrose oil, licorice root, red raspberry leaves, sarsaparilla, spearmint, damiana, motherwort, chasteberry (also known as Vitex), black cohosh, red clover and wild yams. Their relative safety in women who have had breast cancer is not known. God Bless

Her arm and stomach and ribs hurt. He said it was probally from her flu shot and told her not to get the H1N1 yet until he's more sure of how it effects cancer patients. Today, (Sat.) she's had a temp,headache and chills. Tonight, she's better. Soooo, was it a reaction to the flu shot? We don't know, but the onc says the pain in her ribs could be cause it goes through her liver.

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 01:39PM X3sMom wrote: Susan,  Those darn lights on the PET scan...I hate them! I remember when I saw Kendra's liver...it looked like a Christmas tree from one side to the other. Now after 6 chemo's and a liver ablation, she's NED. If your doctor can stop the others, I know the ablation works! I  understand not wanting to tell the kids. There's so much we can't protect them from so this is one area we can control. And as we all hope for miracles, why worry family and friends needlessly if we can believe things will get better. But we do need to pray about the decisions of how much to share with them and when. Continuing to pray for a cure, Glenda

I saw a lady being interviewed the other day by, I think Anderson Cooper, and when she mentioned "stage 4" he ask her what that meant. I wondered if he didn't know or if he used the opportunity to help educate the public. There needs to be more "awareness" of what it means to be stage 4. Hope you get the chance to get more information out there. I know you'll do a great job and make the ladies proud!
Posts.Title: 15 minutes of Fame Fitztwins LRM216

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 01:06PM X3sMom wrote: If you're looking for a 'social network' not talking about sad or depressing issues, talking about things like what you ate, or what you did...Facebook is the place to go. We come here to receive information on tx and se, talking to women who can answer our questions. Women who "get it" when no one else understands how we feel or what we're thinking. If we start to read a thread that's depressing, we can chose which ones we want to continue to read or find another one that may be informitable to us. We can chose not to come here if being Stage 4 is too painful. On this site, it's just as important to be an "encourager". Thank God for you ladies who fall in that category!

Sometimes your insurance plays a part on which test a dr. can use or how often. That may be an issues. If there is progression in your lung, communicate with your dr and take measures to stop it from growing bigger and get rid of it. I'm praying you and your dr. together find what is best for you!

Posts.Content: X3sMom wrote: Kendra's pretty tired tonight, so I wanted to let you gals know her gallbladder surgery went well today. She's sore and swollen and glad it's over. I'm having a hard time keeping her down. She's not used to somebody doing stuff for her. I have to keep saying "sit down, I'll get it". I'm spending a couple days with her and family so she won't over do and has time to heal. Her onc. called today with Pet scan results and said her liver has improved. Her TM's are down to 92.8. Praise the Lord. She doesn't see the onc again until May 22, giving her time to recup before deciding her next battle plan. We really appreciate all you sisters and thank you for your prayers. Blessings, Kendra's mom....aka, Glenda Kendra's Mom Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Kendra's Surgery Update X3sMom heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2010 01:52PM X3sMom wrote: Lynn, I believe excerise is always good if it does hurt and you feel like it. Since you said your energy is low because of tx, it might be good to go to the gym and do a little less, just to get you out of the house. But be careful not to lose to much weight. The side effects of tx may reduce your appetite and you may need a few extra pound to get you thru. My daughter had mets in her pelvis and had a hard time getting up in her jeep because it was too painful. Maybe later, if excerise gets too hard (or painful), you might want to freeze the account....but for now, if it's something you enjoy and it doesn't cause pain, you may want to keep it up. Building up the muscles around your bones is important.
Posts.Title: Anyone Stage IV still going to the gym? Lynn1 KSkier

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 12:18AM - edited Jan 18, 2009 12:19AM by X3sMom 2muchluv,   Kendra is the strongest person I know (I must have done something right raising her). You and your brother are the reason she's so tough. She plans to watch her grandchildren grow up and be as proud of them as I am you two. You're a sensitive young lady and have been through more than your share of trails and heartache. But try to stay positive. Mom has a wonderful caring doctor. I sometimes feel as helpless as you do. Taking her to chemo helps me as much as it does her.  Continue to show her how much you love her and don't forget she needs her rest.  Being a mom and working 40 hrs. a week is hard enough when she's feeling good....one of the best things you do is laying in bed with her just watching tv, laughing and sharing your day with her. You are a precious young lady and I love you. Nonnie

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2010 10:49PM X3sMom wrote:     Dreamwriter...thank you for posting.  I'm so glad you and your daughter have befriended us. Posts.Title: Another Angel - Times3 (Kendra) dreamwriter 3littlegirls

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 12:29AM X3sMom wrote: I'm just 'settling' down after a long day. The funeral was today. They had to set up chairs, so many came to show their love for a strong and couragous young lady. I knew you wonderful ladies would help me thru this difficult time. I can't stop thinking about River's family and dear Little Brother Bobby. Their pain is more real to me now. No words can express the pain I feel as I continue to "be strong". My heart broke even more, if possible, to read of Tony's loss. Mason was a special gal too. Why does it same like God comes for all the good ones? Isn't our hearts broken enough? When will the cure come? Kendra touch everyone who knew her with a beautiful spirit! Her onc and onc nurse came to the funeral home last night in tears. She, like so many other beautiful women, will be greatly missed. On a funny note...I need to tell you sisters that you guys answered all our questions so well and taught us so much...that twice this week people asked me if I was a 'nurse' because I knew what they were taking about and they didn't have to 'draw me a picture'. Good job girls,,,keep the faith and continue to be 'who you are'!

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 01:22PM X3sMom wrote: Patti, you're not alone. Kendra's (Times3) son is 10, on meds for ADHD and had his first anxiety attack last week on the school bus. They had to take him to the er because his heart started racing and other symptoms. After all the test the doctor dx it as a anxiety attack. Then, yesterday his teacher wouldn't let him go to the bathroom and said something to him negatively and he had another one and the school counselor was able to talk him through it. Kendra is checking her insurance and the phone book to find a counselor who can help him deal with his mommy being sick alot and the fear of losing her. We don't know what else to do either. My parents divorced when I was 10 and I know how fragile the mind is at that age.  I pray for peace and wellness for you all.  Blessings, Glenda
